title: US action in Iran risks regional and global nuclear escalation

content:
![Representational Image](https://www.siasat.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/Untitled-design-2026-01-30T105028.141.jpg) Representational Image

**By Farah N. Jan, University of Pennsylvania**

**Harrisburg:** The United States is seemingly moving toward a potential strike on Iran.

On January 28, 2026, President [Donald Trump](https://www.siasat.com/tag/donald-trump/) sharply intensified his threats to the Islamic Republic, suggesting that if [Tehran](https://www.siasat.com/tag/tehran/) did not agree to a set of demands, he could mount an attack “with speed and violence.” To underline the threat, the Pentagon moved aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln – along with destroyers, bombers and fighter jets – to positions within striking distance of the country.

[![Add as a preferred source on Google](https://www.siasat.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/11/preferred_publisher.webp)](https://www.google.com/preferences/source?q=siasat.com)

Foremost among the various demands the U.S. administration has put before Iran’s leader is a permanent end to the country’s uranium enrichment program. It has also called for limits to the development of ballistic missiles and a cutting off of Tehran’s support for proxy groups in the Middle East, including Hamas, Hezbollah and the Houthis.

Trump apparently sees in this moment an opportunity to squeeze an Iran weakened by a poor economy and massive protests that swept through the country in early January.

But as a scholar of Middle Eastern security politics and proliferation, I have concerns. Any U.S. military action now could have widespread unintended consequences later. And that includes the potential for accelerated global nuclear proliferation – regardless of whether the Iranian government is able to survive its current moment of crisis.
